div.p: MRS 203/3, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921, 92/20, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney

Yesterday I came across more specimens of N ro . 261 & 470 near Tintenbar, both flowering and fruiting specimens I reserved for the Museum, but sent a few prefect flowers to Baron von Muller, with notes to help him in his determination. I am very much inclined now to believe that it will be a new species, as it does not agree with the short description in the "Synopsis of the Queensland Flora", and I have made the following rough notes, as forwarded to the Baron:
The anthers are not sessile , but rest on a though

short yet very flexible filament, which in the younger state of the flower is quite bend [sic] over, in such a way as to make the anthers rest in the angle formed by each two petals. When the pollen becomes mature, then the stamens rise up, so that they stand quite upright and surround the stigma pretty closely. I fancy the anthers are divided into four cells. The petals, instead of being membranous are unusually thick and hard
fleshy and somewhat wrinkled. The fruit is not globular , but quite flat at the base and from there tapering pyramidically into the blunt point; the flat base being nearly as much in diam.+
["+1 inch" written in the margin]
as the whole length of the fruit. The stigma also does not appear to me to be obicular The largest leaves I have so far seen and measured were 7 inches long and 2 1/2 inches wide. The highest shrub seen yesterday was 5f but had plenty of [lod]
[bud?]
open and empty fruit capsules.

As the genus Hedraianthera was constituted by the Baron himself, and as so far only one species of it Hedr. porphyropetala is known (also recorded for N.S.W.) I hardly think that the Baron would have named it Hedraianthera since the anthers are not sessile, though there is otherwise so much resemblance between the two, that they might well belong to the same genus, but then the name Hedraianthera might have to be abandoned for one somewhat more appropriate. Would you kindly look for the description of Hedraianthera porthyropetala in the Flora Australiensis? […]
